p: Mango contains different types of carbohydrates based on the stage of maturity. Ripe mango is a rich a source of sugars (fructose, glucose, sucrose), whereas unripe mango is a source of starch and pectin. During the ripening process, starch is converted to fructose and glucose. The increase in mono- and disaccharide concentrations upon maturation is observed in many varieties, including Alphonso [ 30, 31], Deshahari [ 32], and Tommy Atkins [ 33]. Pectin is a gelling sugar and is important for preserving the firmness of the fruit; its levels decrease during the ripening, making the flesh sweeter and smoother [ 26, 34]. Sucrose, fructose, and glucose (in decreasing order of their concentration) are the principal sugars present in mature and ripe mango [ 26, 30, 35].
